description:
The bacterium endosymbiont of Bathymodiolus sp. 5 South is a type of chemoautotrophic bacteria that lives within the gill tissues of the deep-sea mussel species Bathymodiolus sp. 5 South. This endosymbiotic relationship is found in mussels inhabiting deep-sea hydrothermal vent environments.

The bacterium is capable of chemosynthesis, using the oxidation of inorganic compounds, such as hydrogen sulfide, as an energy source to fix carbon dioxide and produce organic compounds that can be utilized by the host mussel. This symbiotic relationship is thought to provide the mussel with a significant portion of its nutritional requirements in the nutrient-poor deep-sea vent environment.

Phylogenetic analyses have shown that this endosymbiont belongs to the phylum Proteobacteria, and is closely related to other chemosynthetic bacteria found in association with deep-sea mussels and other invertebrates from hydrothermal vent and cold seep ecosystems. The specific physiological and genomic characteristics of this endosymbiont are still under investigation to better understand its role in the ecology and adaptation of its Bathymodiolus sp. 5 South host.
